text: [Music]
when we were in
Afghanistan um there was a warlord who
was 14 years old and he had just taken
over his uh his villages from his father
who'd been killed uh just a couple weeks
before we met him and he's in a very
remote region uh just south of the
Animan pass where there was a dividing
uh range um between it was Taliban held
a series of Hills that were Taliban held
and a series of Hills that were held by
his uh villages and he took us up to the
place where his father had been sniped
and uh made it a big point of Pride to
stand at the top of the mountain where
his father had been shot a couple weeks
ago and sort of almost daring the
Taliban who were shooting at us from the
uh from the opposing Hillside you know
we were sort of ducking and covering but
you know this young 14-year-old wanted
to show us that he wasn't afraid to
stand in the exact spot where his father
had been killed and uh and of course the
only way to get up there was on on
Horseback and and I'm no equestrian but
uh I was able to sort of hang on to this
horse uh the photographer I was with
this uh Irish um photographer was uh
unable to ride a horse so he was on a
donkey and um and it was terrifying it
was funny because I was watching him on
a donkey but it was terrifying because
they were shooting at us and he was uh
his name is Sheamus and he's a fantastic
photographer who later became a great
equestrian because he'd learned his
lesson in Afghanistan
